Exaggerate: The claim may be considered exaggerated as it implies that none of the aid has arrived in Ukraine, while the expert's verdict states that about $17 million out of $250 million has not been obligated.
Understate: The claim may be seen as understating the situation as it fails to acknowledge that some aid has indeed arrived in Ukraine.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to back up the assertion that all of the aid has not arrived.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that all of the aid should have arrived by a certain time, without considering any potential delays or complications in the delivery process.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's verdict provides an alternative explanation by stating that some senators had to pass additional laws to ensure that the Ukrainians did not lose out on additional funds, contradicting the claim that all of the aid has not arrived.
